text: Answer Question 1 (Section A) and three questions from Section B.
Section A carries 33% of the marks and Section B carries 67% of the marks for this paper.
You have 3 hours (plus any pre-agreed individual adjustment) to answer this paper.
Where appropriate (e.g. for formulae, equations, or diagrams) you may hand write or draw on the Inspera paper provided.
<strong>Candidates should not copy and paste figures or content from any other documents.</strong

content: What bonds stabilize alpha-helices and beta-sheets and what is the consequence of these bonds for protein structure?
Explain what makes cellulose better suited as a structural element than glycogen.
How can ion channel function be regulated?
Explain how transporters enable glucose to traverse the intestinal epithelium.
Why is the use of carbon skeletons from the TCA cycle for amino acid synthesis an issue, and how is it solved?
How are fatty acids taken up by the mitochondria?
Draw the main structural components of ATP synthase and outline ways in which it is regulated.
What are ketone bodies, and why do they form?
How did Benzer identify discrete units of recombination using bacteriophage T4?
What three technologies first came together to make gene cloning a reality in the 1970s? Briefly describe the experimental steps needed to clone a gene using these technologies.
Draw a diagram of a prokaryotic replication fork to explain how DNA replication is semi-discontinuous.
When can meiotic chromosomal nondisjunction occur and what are the consequences for gametes? Name a human syndrome that results from nondisjunction.
What is the APC/C and what is its molecular role in triggering the metaphase to anaphase transition?
Why is the calcium ion a ubiquitous second messenger?
What happens at the Mid-Blastula Transition (MBT) and how can the timing of this event be altered experimentally?
What happens at the Mid-Blastula Transition (MBT) and how can the timing of this event be altered experimentally?
Answer three questions. All questions carry equal marks. Suggested total time for this section: 2 hours
<ol start="2">
• Describe how enzymes increase the rates of reactions over what occurs spontaenously.
• Discuss, with examples, the importance of vesicle fusion in cell biology.
• How are metabolic pathways regulated in eukaryotes? Support your answer with examples.
• Describe the key features of the genetic code. How are the codons in mRNAs correctly identified during initiation, elongation and termination of translation in prokaryotes?
• Describe two distinct examples of cytoplasmic inheritance in eukaryotes. In what ways is cytoplasmic inheritance non-Mendelian?
• Discuss the basis of Illumina and Nanopore high-throughput sequencing technologies, the advantages of each. Give five examples of how such technologies contribute to our understanding of biology.
• Discuss the importance of checkpoints in cell cycle control and why mutations in checkpoint genes are often associated with inherited susceptibility to cancer.
• Compare the modes of actions of the major classes of plasma membranelocalised receptors found in animal cells.
• Experiments are important in developmental biology. Discuss two physical and two genetic experiments that have informed our understanding of how animals develop.

2024p.name: BOC/WP: Biology of Cells - Written Practical

text: You have 3 hours (plus any pre-agreed individual adjustment) to answer this paper.
Where appropriate (e.g. for formulae, equations, or diagrams) you may hand write or draw on the Inspera paper provided.
<strong>Candidates should not copy and paste figures or content from any other documents.</strong

content: You are given the specimens listed below (i-vi) and asked to obtain images that will provide answers to the experimental questions that follow.
For each specimen state which microscopical technique you could use:
Note: The marks are given for the entire question.
<center>Cells of the giant algae, Chara, to determine the speed of cytoplasmic streaming.</center>
You are given the specimens listed below (i-vi) and asked to obtain images that will provide answers to the experimental questions that follow.
For each specimen state which microscopical technique you could use:
<center>Mammalian hepatocytes, to estimate the width of the lumen of the rough endoplasmic reticulum.</center>
You are given the specimens listed below (i-vi) and asked to obtain images that will provide answers to the experimental questions that follow.
For each specimen state which microscopical technique you could use:
<center>Rat pancreatic cells, to assess the distribution of nucleic acids.</center>
You are given the specimens listed below (i-vi) and asked to obtain images that will provide answers to the experimental questions that follow.
For each specimen state which microscopical technique you could use:
<center>Chara cells, to study the localisation of the protein myosin fused to green fluorescent protein.</center>
You are given the specimens listed below (i-vi) and asked to obtain images that will provide answers to the experimental questions that follow.
For each specimen state which microscopical technique you could use:
<center>Living buccal epithelial cells, to estimate the number of cells in a sample of saliva.</center>
You are given the specimens listed below (i-vi) and asked to obtain images that will provide answers to the experimental questions that follow.
For each specimen state which microscopical technique you could use:
<center>An unknown virus, to determine its morphology.</center>
Briefly describe how the Chara samples in (i) and hepatocyte samples in (ii) would be prepared for the respective microscopy techniques.
When would you use scanning electron microscopy and when would you use transmission electron microscopy to analyse a sample? For each method give an example of a specimen that could be examined.
